Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Web.Mobile.dll assembly has been deprecated and should no longer be used. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=157231.")

Docs.summary: Provides the capability to group controls together. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A form represents the outermost grouping of controls within an ASP.NET mobile Web page. An individual mobile Web page can contain multiple forms at the outermost level. Forms cannot be nested; use <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel> controls if you want to nest containers. For more information, see [Introduction to the Form Control](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-3.0/dxzx3ss0(v=vs.85)). To display a specific form, either set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage.ActiveForm%2A> property on the current page to the desired form, or set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link.NavigateUrl%2A> property in a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control to the desired form. You can include literal text along with its accompanying markup tags in the text contents of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> control. When using templates, it is important to remember that the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> control creates instances of templates in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method for the form. The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method for the form is called before `Page_Load` and `Page_Init`. Also, the page constructor executes too early to set templates in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method because the form is not yet created. To correct this, hook the form's own <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method, and create an instance of the template there. For more information, see [Implementing Templated Rendering](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b86d9d1d-ab18-4cad-a825-092826bb3922).
## Examples The following code example shows how to create a page with two forms along with links between the two forms. One form has a check box list. When items are selected and the **Submit** button is clicked, the form presents a list of the selected items and their values. Notice that the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Activate> event methods prepare the respective forms for display
> [!NOTE] > The following code example uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code example must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Syntax Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/09074b20-ece9-46fa-bc8f-ab2595ed2c02).
[!code-aspx-csharp[MobileFormSample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[MobileFormSample#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default.aspx#1)]

Docs.permission: for operating in a hosted environment. Demand value: ; Permission value: .

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL to which the form is submitted. The default value is an empty string (""). This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The URL to which the form is submitted.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The default value, an empty string (""), causes postbacks to the page containing the current form. You can override the default value to submit the form to a different URL.
> [!NOTE] > If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Action%2A> property is inherited, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control posts form contents to the inherited URL.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event Activate As EventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when a form becomes active. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Activate> event occurs under the following circumstances:
- When a page is first requested, the first form is activated.
- When the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage.ActiveForm%2A> property of the page is set programmatically.
- When the user navigates to a form through a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control whose target is a form.
This event's position in the event chain makes it very important for binding child controls to data sources or for setting a form property that can be inherited by all child controls.
## Examples The following code example shows how to set the `OnActivate` attribute in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> element to point to a method that executes when the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Activate> event occurs. The `Form2_Activate` method prepares the second form for display. This example is part of a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> overview.
> [!NOTE] > The following code example uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code example must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Syntax Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/09074b20-ece9-46fa-bc8f-ab2595ed2c02).
[!code-csharp[MobileFormSample#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/cs/Default.aspx#3)] [!code-vb[MobileFormSample#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default.aspx#3)] [!code-aspx-vb[MobileFormSample#8](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default2.aspx#8)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Web::UI::Control ^ ControlToPaginate { System::Web::UI::Control ^ get(); void set(System::Web::UI::Control ^ value); };
member this.ControlToPaginate : System.Web.UI.Control with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the control on the form that can be paginated. The default is ( in Visual Basic). This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The control on the form that can be paginated.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.ControlToPaginate%2A> property is used to allow a single control on a form to paginate its contents across several views on mobile devices and providing next and previous navigation between views. A control can paginate its contents even if a containing <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel> control has its <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel.Paginate%2A> property set to `false`.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.ControlToPaginate%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> class to specify which control to paginate.
The example creates a page with two forms. One form has a very long string that on some devices must be paginated to give the user access to the entire text. In order to see the pagination in action, you must view the example on a device that handles pagination. In [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)], you can use one of the device emulators available with the **Device Emulator Manager** on the **Tools** menu.
> [!NOTE] > The following code example uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code example must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Syntax Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/09074b20-ece9-46fa-bc8f-ab2595ed2c02).
[!code-aspx-csharp[MobileFormSample#4](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/cs/Default2.aspx#4)] [!code-aspx-vb[MobileFormSample#4](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default2.aspx#4)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event Deactivate As EventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when an active form becomes inactive. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A form becomes inactive under the following circumstances:
- When the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage.ActiveForm%2A> property of the page is programmatically set to another form.
- When the user navigates to a form through a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control whose target is a form.
If neither of these actions occurs, the active form will never receive a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Deactivate> event. This event's position in the event chain makes it very important in resetting the child controls, data set, or global variables.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to trap the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Deactivate> event to clear the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.SelectionList>. This example is part of a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> overview.
[!code-csharp[MobileFormSample#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/cs/Default.aspx#2)] [!code-vb[MobileFormSample#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default.aspx#2)]

Docs.value: The that represents the footer for the form.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Footer%2A> property to access the contents of the `FooterTemplate`.
This example is from a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.ControlToPaginate%2A> property.
[!code-csharp[MobileFormSample#5](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/cs/Default2.aspx#5)] [!code-vb[MobileFormSample#5](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default2.aspx#5)]
In this example, since no filter is specified for the `<Choice>` element, it will always be the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.DeviceSpecific.SelectedChoice%2A>. To specify a filter change the element to: `<Choice Filter="isPocketIE">` and include a Web.config file that defines the filters you want to use.
[!code-aspx-vb[MobileFormSample#8](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default2.aspx#8)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance class System.Collections.IList GetLinkedForms(int32 optimumPageWeight) cil managed
Public Function GetLinkedForms (optimumPageWeight As Integer) As IList

Docs.param: The total weight for the target device of the resulting linked forms must not exceed (used in pagination). If its value is -1, the total weight will not be considered when linked forms are added to the list.
Docs.summary: Returns a set of forms that are linked to the current form. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.returns: A set of forms that are linked to the current form.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When a form contains navigation elements that activate another form without interacting with the server, it is considered to be a linked form. There are several factors involved for a form to be considered linked. For example, if the following three stipulations are met, Form B is considered to be one of the forms linked to Form A:
- Form A contains a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control with its destination as Form B.
- Form A does not contain an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnDeactivate%2A> event handler.
- Form B has no <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnActivate%2A> event handler.
The distinction is the set of all forms that do not require server interactions to transfer control between.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the method used to submit the form. The default value is . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The method used to submit the form.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A `get` request is limited in the amount of data it can post. Some types of postbacks might fail when using a `get` request. The advantage of a `get` request is that all the parameters are specified as part of the URL, and the URL can be cached or saved. The elements of a `post` request are contained within the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Form%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.

Docs.param: An object that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Raises the event. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When notified by this method, server controls must perform any initialization steps that are required to create and set up an instance. In this stage of the server control's lifecycle, the control's view state has yet to be populated. Additionally, you cannot access other server controls when this method is called either, regardless of whether it is a child or parent to this control. Other server controls are not certain to be created and ready for access.

Docs.exception: The form is contained by another form.
Docs.related: Introduction to the ASP.NET Page Life Cycle

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property PageCount As Integer
public: property int PageCount { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns the number of pages in the form after the form is paginated. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The number of pages in the form after the form is paginated.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> control exposes the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.PageCount%2A> property and the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.CurrentPage%2A> property, which provide information about how the current form is paginated. The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.PageCount%2A> property also helps provide navigation capability to another page. For example, when rendering on a richer device, a search results form might include device-specific UI elements that allow the user to browse to a page of results by number rather than by link navigation.
> [!NOTE] > This value is available after the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Paginated> event has occurred. To get the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.PageCount%2A> property, you can handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Paginated> event of the form.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.PageCount%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> control. This code example is part of a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.ControlToPaginate%2A> property.
[!code-csharp[MobileFormSample#5](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/cs/Default2.aspx#5)] [!code-vb[MobileFormSample#5](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileFormSample/vb/Default2.aspx#5)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event Paginated As EventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when a form is paginated. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A form is paginated prior to rendering each request. After pagination is complete, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Paginated> event occurs. After this event occurs, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.CurrentPage%2A> property of the form contains the actual number of pages for the form.
## Examples For a complete code example, see the example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.ControlToPaginate%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the title of the specified form. The default value is an empty . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The title can be rendered as part of the form, on devices that support a title separate from page content (for example, on the title bar of a browser using the title tag in HTML).

remarks.format: ## Remarks For devices that support a title separate from the page content, you can render the title as part of the form.
